Function reference

Create balancing formulas

Creates balancing formulas relating exposure to all relevant time-varying and time invariant confounders at each exposure time point to be used to create IPTW weights.

createFormulas()
Create balancing formulas

Create IPTW balancing weights

IPTW balancing weights (Thoemmes & Ong, 2016) using the createWeights() function, the shortened balancing formulas, and all available weighting methods.

createWeights()
Creates IPTW balancing weights

Trim IPTW balancing weights (if needed)

Trims IPTW balancing weights with heavy right tails by populating all weight values above a given quantile with the weight value of that quantile.

trimWeights()
Trim IPTW balancing weights

Assess balance

Draws on functions from the cobalt package to quantify the relations between exposure and confounders at each exposure time point according to the guidelines from Jackson, 2016 on how to assess balance for time-varying exposures.

assessBalance()
Assesses confounder balancing

Fit weighted marginal outcome model

Fits weighted marginal outcome model as a generalized linear model of the user’s choosing, relating exposure main effects to outcome using IPTW weights.

fitModel()
Fit outcome model

Estimate, compare, and visualize exposure histories

Takes fitted model output to created predicted values for user-specified histories (pooling for imputed data), before conducting contrast comparisons (pooling for imputed data), correcting for multiple comparisons, and then plotting results.

compareHistories()
Estimate, compare, and visualize exposure histories

Helper functions (assessBalance)

calcBalStats()
Calculate balance stats based on Jackson paper
make_love_plot()
Create love plots showing balancing statistics

Helper functions (fitModel)

getModel()
Fits outcome model

Helper functions (compareHistories)

add_dose()
Add dose tally to table
add_histories()
Add history labels to table
create_custom_comparisons()
Creates custom comparisons
create_custom_contrasts()
Create custom contrasts
eval_hist()
Visualize distribution of sample across exposure histories
get_comparison_values()
Finds custom comparison values
get_reference_values()
Finds custom reference values
perform_multiple_comparison_correction()
Conduct multiple comparison correction

Example simulated datasets

These example datasets are used throughout the vignettes

sim_data_imp_list
Wide data imputed and read in (continuous exposure)
sim_data_long_miss
Long data with missingness (continuous exposure)
sim_data_long_miss_bin
Long data with missingness (binary exposure)
sim_data_mice
Wide data imputed with mice (continuous exposure)
sim_data_wide
Wide complete data (continuous exposure) These data are simulated based on data from the Family Life Project (FLP), a longitudinal study following 1,292 families representative of two geographic areas (three counties in North Carolina and three counties in Pennsylvania) with high rural child poverty (Vernon-Feagans et al., 2013; Burchinal et al., 2008). These data contain economic strain (ESEATA1) as a continuously distributed variable and have no missing data.
sim_data_wide_bin
Wide complete data (binary exposure) These data are simulated based on data from the Family Life Project (FLP), a longitudinal study following 1,292 families representative of two geographic areas (three counties in North Carolina and three counties in Pennsylvania) with high rural child poverty (Vernon-Feagans et al., 2013; Burchinal et al., 2008). These data contain economic strain (ESEATA1) as a binary variable, and have no missing data.
sim_data_wide_miss
Wide data with missingness (continuous exposure)
sim_data_wide_miss_bin
Wide data with missingness (binary exposure)
